headline.main: AT YORKTOWN, CUISINE TAKES OVER FROM MUSKETRY

byline.original: By BEN A. FRANKLIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The smudgy ambience of campfires under pots of gruel at the 1,000-tent bivouac of the citizen ''army'' here for the mock battles of the Yorktown victory bicentennial was outsniffed today by the more exotic aromas of well-to-do 18th-century kitchens and contemporary French haute cuisine. But the culinary maneuvers were not for the rank and file of ''flintlock freaks,'' the uniformed volunteers from 23 states who are portraying the 1,000 Redcoats and 2,000 Continentals who daily do combat with black powder blanks on the battlefield. It was a day of gustatory workouts for the European chefs assigned to feed, in formal glitter, a 20th-century ''court'' of distinguished visitors. They included the Presidents of the United States and France, a cadre of cabinet secretaries and ministers of the two governments, the governors of scores of states and a long list of ambassadors, senators, descendants of the French military heroes of Yorktown and wealthy patrons of Colonial Williamsburg and their ladies.

headline.main: Montreal Mayor's Restaurant Combines Cuisine and Culture

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HOTELS, BART, MOTELS, NIGHT CLUBS AND RESTAURANTS

docs.abstract: Montreal, Canada, restaurant, operated by Mayor Drapeau, offers classical music by 20 instrumentalists; patrons are virtually sworn to silence during performances
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL, Dec. 29 -- This gourmets' haven has added a major new restaurant to its already large assortment, and the first thing that makes it unusual is a doorman who neither accepts tips nor offers protection against parking tickets.

headline.main: A Japanese Cuisine With Style and Spark

docs.abstract: Patricia Brooks reviews Yooki Yama restaurant in Branford, Conn (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: EXCEPT for the dolls, the folk art and the doodads for sale above and behind the sushi bar, Yooki Yama in Branford looks like many other Japanese storefront restaurants. No special frills. No special ethnicity. What is different about Yooki Yama, though, is the menu.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese food, movie popcorn, Mexican food -- the Center for Science in the Public Interest has been slamming them all recently, mostly for the fat content. Do ordinary citizens know what's bad for them? A spontaneous, unscientific telephone poll of 25 people produced some information of unknown reliability. It suggests that one message is getting through loud and clear -- fat is bad. Asked what kind of food is worst for your health, the respondents chose, in order, American fast food -- 5; Mexican -- 4; Southern/soul food -- 4; Eastern European -- 2; all American food -- 2, and 1 each for Cajun, Lithuanian, Salvadoran, whatever is greasiest, German, French, Russian and undecided.
docs.snippet: Chinese food, movie popcorn, Mexican food -- the Center for Science in the Public Interest has been slamming them all recently, mostly for the fat content. Do ordinary citizens know what's bad for them?   A spontaneous, unscientific telephone poll...

headline.main: A Rural Plateau and Its Earthy Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: I DISCOVERED Puglia about 15 years ago while seeking a route from Rome to Greece. There had to be an alternative to the long, boring train ride to the Brindisi ferry; there had at least to be something to see on the way. The logical place to begin looking was the region to which the port of Brindisi belongs, Puglia. As an archeology student, I knew a few things about the area: that the modern region of Puglia corresponds to ancient Apulia plus ancient Calabria, which has nothing to do with modern Calabria; that there were pre-Greek people called Apuli, Peucetii and Messapii; that the museum of Taranto, the Spartan colony of Taras and later Roman Tarentum, was worth any amount of difficulty to see; that in 37 B.C. the Roman poet Horace had had any amount of difficulty getting to Brundisium, terminus of the Via Appia; and that Virgil had died there on his way back from Greece in 19 B.C. The modern version of the trip did not offer hope that the poets' experiences had been exceptional.
